sub_topic: Precision measurements of the weak interaction
message_1: What is the  decay width of the Z boson in the Standard Model, and how does it compare to the experimental measurements at particle accelerator experiments such as the Large Hadron Collider?
message_2:
The decay width of a particle is a measure of its decay rate, which is related to its lifetime. In the Standard Model of particle physics, the Z boson is a neutral, massive vector boson that mediates the weak force. Its decay width can be calculated theoretically using the principles of quantum field theory and electroweak interactions.

The total decay width of the Z boson (Γ_Z) in the Standard Model is approximately 2.4952 GeV. This value is obtained by summing up the partial decay widths for all possible decay channels of the Z boson, which include decays into quark-antiquark pairs, charged lepton-antilepton pairs, and neutrino-antineutrino pairs.

Experimental measurements of the Z boson decay width have been performed at particle accelerator experiments, such as those at the Large Electron-Positron Collider (LEP) at CERN and the Stanford Linear Collider (SLC). The combined results from these experiments give a measured value of Γ_Z = 2.495 ± 0.0023 GeV.

The agreement between the theoretical prediction and the experimental measurements of the Z boson decay width is excellent, which provides strong support for the validity of the Standard Model. The Large Hadron Collider (LHC) at CERN continues to study the properties of the Z boson and other particles, further testing the predictions of the Standard Model and searching for new physics beyond it.
